description: Examples for language grammar flashcards - structural rules, conjugations, syntax patterns

examples.title: Spanish Preterite - To Speak
examples.front_question_text: How do you say 'I spoke' in Spanish?
examples.front_question_context: Using the verb 'hablar' in preterite tense
examples.front_question_example: Ayer _____ con mi madre. (Yesterday I spoke with my mother)
examples.back_explanation: Preterite form of 'hablar' for first person singular. Regular -ar verbs in preterite end in -é for 'yo'.
examples.back_mnemonics: AR verbs: é, aste, ó, amos, asteis, aron

examples.title: Second Conditional Structure
examples.front_question_text: Complete the second conditional: If I _____ rich, I _____ buy a house.
examples.front_question_hint: Use past tense in if-clause, would + infinitive in main clause
examples.back_explanation: Second conditional structure: If + past simple, would + infinitive. Uses 'were' for all persons with the verb 'be'.

examples.title: German Dative Case - Indirect Object
examples.front_question_text: What is the dative form of 'der Mann' (the man)?
examples.front_question_hint: Used for indirect objects and certain prepositions
examples.back_explanation: In dative case, 'der' (masculine) becomes 'dem'. The dative case indicates the indirect object or is used with dative prepositions.
examples.back_mnemonics: Dative masculine: DeM Mann - 'Dem' sounds like 'them' (giving TO them)

examples.title: French Subjunctive - To Be
examples.front_question_text: What is 'I am' in French subjunctive?
examples.front_question_example: Il faut que je _____ là. (I need to be there)
examples.back_explanation: The subjunctive form of 'être' for 'je' is 'sois'. Used after expressions of necessity, emotion, or doubt.
examples.back_mnemonics: Je sois - sounds like 'swah' - the swaying uncertain feeling of subjunctive

examples.title: Italian Articulated Prepositions - Di + Il
examples.back_explanation: When preposition 'di' (of/from) combines with definite article 'il' (the), they form 'del'. This is called an articulated preposition.
examples.back_mnemonics: 'Del' sounds like 'dell' - the dell OF the mountain

examples.title: Portuguese Imperative - You (informal)
examples.front_question_text: How do you say 'Speak!' (informal) in Portuguese?
examples.back_explanation: Imperative of 'falar' for 'tu' drops the final 's' from present tense 'falas' → 'fala'. Used for informal commands.

examples.title: Russian Genitive Plural - Hard Feminine
examples.front_question_text: What is the genitive plural of 'мама' (mom)?
examples.front_question_context: Genitive plural of hard feminine nouns
examples.front_question_hint: Used after numbers and in 'много' constructions
examples.back_explanation: Hard feminine nouns ending in -а drop the ending entirely in genitive plural. 'мама' → 'мам'.
examples.back_mnemonics: Hard feminines: just drop the ending completely - мама → мам

examples.title: Japanese Te-form - Group 1 Verbs
examples.front_question_text: What is the te-form of '読む' (yomu - to read)?
examples.front_question_hint: む/ぶ/ぬ endings become んで in te-form
examples.back_explanation: Verbs ending in む, ぶ, or ぬ change to んで in te-form. 読む → 読んで. Te-form is used for progressive tense and connecting actions.
examples.back_mnemonics: MuBuNu → NDE: む/ぶ/ぬ becomes んで
